characters: TIGHT ON THE TELEVISION. A WELL-DRESSED BLACK WOMAN
FROM OUT OF NOWHERE, DEREK TAKES A MOP TO THE OWNER'S

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young man's blue eyes slowly open.  A girl moans from t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: turns the corner and splashes through a puddle from an earlier rain. TUPAC SHAKUR blares from inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They snap wide as the young woman in the next room MOANS even louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A slight buzz emanates from the power lines and street lights above the humble VINYARD household. A black FORD BRONCO rests in the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TUPAC'S rapping builds. The window-tinted drive-by slowly heads down the residential street, cruises past the Bronco in the driveway, and slows to a stop. The music stops and TWO BLACK MEN spring from the car. They move with purpose. The larger figure, crowbar in hand, moves to the truck. The GUN wielding passenger hurries to the front door and stands guard. Inside the car, another man methodically waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sex happening in the next room makes it difficult for Danny to sleep. Next to a digital clock that reads 3:07AM, the clean cut 14-year-old flips to his side. A poster of Lee Ving of FEAR onstage, taped to the wall. Pre-Calculus and Biology books on the floor. Cassettes scattered on his tiny desk. A stereo in the corner. The off-screen sound of breaking glass grabs Danny's attention. He sits up and looks through the blinds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny SEES a man reach through the broken window and unlock the door. He quickly. pans to the idling Trans Am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His fearful expression says it all.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Holy shit. Danny quickly bolts out of his room and into the adjacent bedroom down the hall. He barges through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It hangs above a serious computer and next to a giant, tome-filled bookshelf. The moans, meanwhile, approach orgasm. TIGHT ON DEREK VINYARD. The young man has a shaved head, a thick goatee, and a well-crafted SWASTIKA on his left tit. On top of Derek in the bed is his barely-of-age girlfriend, STACEY. The covers are completely off and a BLACK ROSE is tattooed across her right shoulder blade. Danny watches her fuck, only for a second.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (softly) Der ! Danny walks over and shakes him. Startled, Derek forcefully grabs his little brother's arm.

dialogues.speaker: DEREK
dialogues.text: (controlled) What? Stacey stops and looks over.  Frustated, she rolls off Derek and onto her side.

dialogues.speaker: STACEY
dialogues.text: Fucking pervert, Dan!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: There's a black guy outside Der... breaking into your car. Derek, muscled and tattooed, jumps out of the bed and quickly puts on his skivvies. He reaches under his mattress, pulls out a SIG .45 semi-automatic pistol, and shoves in a clip.

dialogues.speaker: DEREK
dialogues.text: How long has he been out there?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Not long.

dialogues.speaker: STACEY
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: DEREK
dialogues.text: Nobody. Relax. Stacey sits up quickly from the bed as Derek pulls on his black combat boots.

dialogues.speaker: STACEY
dialogues.text: Who's out there, Derek?

dialogues.speaker: DEREK
dialogues.text: Not right now, honey. (to Danny) How many?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: One...I think.

dialogues.speaker: DEREK
dialogues.text: Is he strapped?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Hunh?

dialogues.speaker: DEREK
dialogues.text: Does he have a fucking gun, Dan?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I'm not sure.

dialogues.speaker: DEREK
dialogues.text: Is there a driver? Danny nods his head yes.

dialogues.speaker: DEREK
dialogues.text: Okay.  Stay the luck here.

dialogues.speaker: STACEY
dialogues.text: Derek? Be careful. He looks at his girlfriend and walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT ON DEREK. He walks down the hall. The intensity on his face is alarming. He stops at the front door and grabs the doorknob. Before he turns the knob, he peeks through the eye hole on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE BLACK GUARD carelessly turns toward the driveway to see what's taking his partner so long with the wires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guard has his back to him. Derek goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derek throws open the door and the black man standing guard wheels and fires a shot into the front door. Derek buries two bullets in his chest.

dialogues.speaker: DEREK
dialogues.text: Fuck you! The force propels the man six feet backwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stunned by the gunfire, he charges back to the getaway Tranny. Derek buries a bullet into his shoulder. The car splits and Derek fires a shot through the side window. He then walks towards the car and fires shot after shot at it until it disappears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Davina and Doris Vinyard yell in the background like they were in Vietnam. They meet in the hallway, still not able to place the direction of the gunfire.

dialogues.speaker: STAY DOWN, HONEY
dialogues.text: They stay down on the carpet together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the rain-soaked window he watches Derek face his wounded prey - crawling on the ground. Sirens sound from a distance.

dialogues.speaker: STACEY, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Get down, Danny! Jesus! TIGHT ON DANNY. His gaze is locked on his brother from his bedroom window. Derek cocks his piece, points it and walks toward the man. TIGHT ON DEREK'S FACE. Eyes blistering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black man in a suit and tie, ROBERT SWEENEY, goes through the automatic doors and into the station. He approaches a DESK SERGEANT. A daily calendar on her desk reads MONDAY. MARCH 3. 1997.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: Captain Rasmussen?

dialogues.speaker: DESK SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Briefing room. Down that hall...third door on the left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cops and detectives sit attentively and a few sip coffee. The clock on the wall above reads 7:38 AM. Middle-aged with slicked-back hair, CAPTAIN JOHN RASMUSSEN finishes a thought. He spots Sweeney as he enters and aimlessly reaches for a file.

dialogues.speaker: RASMUSSEN
dialogues.text: All right. Moving on-- (acknowledging) Good Morning, Doctor. The group looks over and meets Sweeney's hard glare.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: RASMUSSEN
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, this is Dr. Bob Sweeney. He's Principal over at Venice High and for some time now he's done a load of outreach work with gangs...in and out of the can. Sweeney nods as Rasmussen cough.  He sips water and continues.

dialogues.speaker: RASMUSSEN
dialogues.text: Three years ago a local kid named Derek Vinyard gets sent up for murdering a couple of Crips who were trying to jack his car. Bob taught Vinyard back in high school and has followed the case closely.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG COP
dialogues.text: He was a skinhead, right?

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: Derek was more like...the skinhead. He and Cameron Alexander.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Who? Rasmussen opens a FILE in front of him. There rests Derek's mug shot. He flips it over and reveals CAMMERON'S MUG SHOT. Front and side view.

dialogues.speaker: RASMUSSEN
dialogues.text: Cammeron Alexander is probably the biggest writer and distributor of white power literature in LA County. He promotes white power bands, writes reviews, columns, all at the ripe age of forty.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG COP
dialogues.text: (smiling) He's forty? Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: RASMUSSEN
dialogues.text: Pretty clean record...runs everything out of his house down by the beach.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: There weren't any organized white gangs around Venice before those two hooked up. Very few, if any. It was mostly just black and Mexican. But it was tiny. They hit it off though... and Alexander hit the jackpot with Derek. Rasmussen reaches over and pushes play on a VCR.

dialogues.speaker: RASMUSSEN
dialogues.text: We got some uncut footage here. Courtesy of NBC.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Earlier this evening...LA County Firefighter Dennis Vinyard was shot and killed while putting out a fire in a suspected Compton drug den.

dialogues.speaker: RASMUSSEN
dialogues.text: (to the group) This being February of '90.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A YOUNGER DEREK, short haired with no tattoos, stands next to the reporter. Derek wears a Venice High Basketball jersey drenched in sweat. Towel around neck, he thinks to himself as the man speaks into the camera.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: To my right I have Lieutenant Vinyard's oldest son Derek. (to Derek) How do you feel about all this, son?

dialogues.speaker: DEREK
dialogues.text: How do I feel? How do you think I feel? It's typical.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Typical how, Derek?

dialogues.speaker: DEREK
dialogues.text: Well...look at our country. It's a haven for criminals. Black...brown... yellow...whatever.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: So you're saying the murder of your father is "race" related?

dialogues.speaker: DEREK
dialogues.text: Every problem in this country is "race" related. Every problem, not just crime. These problems are rooted in the black community, the Hispanic community, the Asian...every non- Protestant group in our society. (then) Look at the shit. Immigration... welfare...AIDS...they're all the problems of the non-white. Look at the statistics.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Most of these issues you're referring to though son are related to--

dialogues.speaker: DEREK
dialogues.text: (interrupting) No no no! Don't say poverty right now cause that's not it. They're not a product of our fucking environment either! Minorities don't give two shits about this country! They're here to exploit...not embrace.

dialogues.speaker: RASMUSSEN, (O.S)
dialogues.text: (over reporter's question) When Alexander got his hands on this segment...he copied it, sent it out and it became the Gettysberg Address for hate groups across the country. BACK TO THE TELEVISION.

dialogues.speaker: DEREK
dialogues.text: Millions of white Europeans came to this country and flourished within a generation! A generation! So what the fuck is wrong with these people?!

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: What does any of this have to do with your father?

dialogues.speaker: DEREK
dialogues.text: Because my father was doing his fucking job! Saving a nigger neighborhood he didn't give two shits about! And he got killed by some drug dealer who still collects a fucking welfare check. Derek looks at the man and walks over to HIS MOTHER DORIS, who smokes a cigarette. The camera follows him as he puts his arm around her and escorts her back inside their Venice Beach residence. The camera pans back to the reporter who just stands there, speechless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rasmussen ejects the tape, the screen turns to fuzz, and he turns it off.

dialogues.speaker: RASMUSSEN
dialogues.text: Vinyard was quietly released from Chino on Saturday after three and some odd years. And I think it's something we might want to keep an eye on for a few days.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: I don't wanna be an alarmist. But payback is out there. I know it is. And in this particular case...if Vinyard gets popped...more people will get popped.

dialogues.speaker: RASMUSSEN
dialogues.text: It's not exactly LAPD policy but I want 24-hour surveillance on Vinyard for a few days.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: (smiling in disbelief) Twenty-four hour surveillance, sir?

dialogues.speaker: RASMUSSEN
dialogues.text: Just for a few days.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER COP
dialogues.text: He doesn't sound like Mr. Lovely here, Captain. You want us to bust him or protect him? Rasmussen offers Sweeney a look that it's his question.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: I don't think Vinyard's gonna be the one to start anything. It's his following.

dialogues.speaker: RASMUSSEN
dialogues.text: Either way...let's keep it low.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PEACEFUL DAY by PENNYWISE blasts from Danny's walkman headphones. The day is cloudy and overcast but that doesn't bother the local SURFERS. A twosome paddles north to get a better break on the next set. Danny watches as he skateboards down the strand. His appearance is changed, now resembling a younger, softer Derek. Head shaved to a quarter of an inch, he wears a PLAIN WHITE BACKPACK with punk/white power bands scribbled all over it. Your standard Sex Pistols, DK, Germs, G.B.M., and Adolescents in black. Cro-Magnons and Skrewdriver off to the left. In red is the largest name, DICK NIXON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids from all walks of life park their cars, lock their bikes and head off to class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny throws his SKATEBOARD in, slams the door, and turns to face LIZZY, a pretty, redheaded freshman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Danny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Lizzy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two smile at one another as the FIRST BELL RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Danny takes a piss. Outside, a voice pleads "It wasn't me!" DARYL DAWSON, pale and thin, is shoved into the bathroom and he trips into the sink. LITTLE HENRY, a young black kid, enters with two of his buddies. Danny zips up and faces them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to a terrified Daryl) Tellin' Baker I'm fuckin' cheatin'? I've never cheated in my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat his ass, Henry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why you trippin' on me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say anything, Henry. I swear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's lying, man! I was right there! Little Henry cracks Daryl in the face and practically knocks him down with one shot. A bleeding Daryl struggles to his hands and knees behind Danny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time, man. Danny stares into Henry's eyes and the trio exits. Dannv helps Daryl back up to the sink. THE SECOND BELL RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids have just settled into their seats.  Danny walks in  and tries to be discrete.

dialogues.speaker: OFFSCREEN VOICE
dialogues.text: Vinyard!? An OLDER TEACHER writes an Algebra problem on the board for the students to solve.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER TEACHER
dialogues.text: You're late. The man grabs a pink slip off his desk and hands it to Danny.

dialogues.speaker: OLD TEACHER
dialogues.text: But it looks like you got bigger problems.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: (reading the slip) Oh, man! Come on. Get a job. The teacher stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits in a chair next to an office door marked DR. ROBERT SWEENEY - PRINCIPAL. Danny glances at the secretary as she types and talks on the phone. TIGHT ON DANNY. He listens to the conversation through the the crack in the door as his eyes swell.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: I do not have a problem with him as an individual, alright!?

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh shit Murray sure you do.  You hate this kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bespectacled, short-haired MURRAY ROSENBERG, 48, looks over and spots Danny listening outside. Murray walks over and shuts the door. He looks at DR. SWEENEY, who now has his jacket off. He points to a typewritten report on the desk and smiles in horror. It is titled BOOK REPORT--MEIN KAMPF. "Daniel Vinvard - American History" is in the upper left hand corner.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: This paper is a travesty, Bob! Arguing for Hitler as a civil rights hero?! You've gotta draw a line.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: Murray...it says in your syllabus that they could do their report on any book related to the struggle for Civil Rights.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: Oh come on, Bob!

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: Let me finish! He needs help...I'm not disputing that. But I read it and I'm not going to throw him out.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: His brother probably put him up to it.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: I can guarantee you his brother didn't have anything to do with it, Murray. Murray sighs and takes off his glasses.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: Don't let him walk scot-free here. For his sake...not mine. You might be all he has left. Sweeney stares at the younger teacher and nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murray walks out and turns back to Sweeney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Get in here, Dan! Danny and Murray make hostile eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it was you. SWEENEY (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up and get your ass in here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before he even gets through the door he's chastised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it gonna be, Dan? DANNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's what going to be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This petty shit you're pullin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said it, all right. Sit down. Danny does what he's told. Sweeney stares at the teenager and leans back in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay? DANNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any time you wanna talk, Dan-- DANNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's Derek? DANNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: Adjusting okay?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: He was a student of mine. Honors English. He was a great student... like you...but he hung out with scumbags. Also like you. That's why he ended up in the pen, hunh? No answer. Sweeney holds up Danny's paper.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: Great writing. I can't correct it though. It wreaks too much of shit.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Come on, man! I followed directions and wrote an "A" paper. It's got nothing to do with Derek.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: Everything you do now has something to do with Derek. Who told you to do this?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Let us get on with our lives, man!

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: Hey, I'm not worried about Derek--he can take care of himself.  I'm worried about his little brother. (softly) Mein Kampf, Dan? I should expel you!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Do it. What?  You don't think I could handle it?

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: (smiling in disbelief) The street would kill you, Danny. You're not tough. The second a brother pulls a gun on your ass you'll be holierin' for Doris. (pondering to himself) So here's the drill. Take it or leave it cause I'm sick of babysitting. I'm your history teacher from here on out. We're gonna deal with shit happening right now. Call it American History...X. I see your ass once a day. Any more, any less, and you're a memory at Venice High. Clear?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It took me a week to read Mein Kampf. Come on, Sweeney.

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: My name is Dr. Sweeney. And I want a another paper on my desk tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: What am I doing it on then?

dialogues.speaker: SWEENEY
dialogues.text: It'S not a "what", it's a "who." (after a beat) Derek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A series of intercuts shows activity in and around the pier. A HOMELESS LATINO MAN searches a trash dumpster. OPEN VENDORS sell tie-dye and water bong paraphernalia. A FAT WOMAN walks past eating a hot dog. BLACK GANG MEMBERS play basketball in their low-rider shorts and boxers. TIGHT ON DANNY. He skateboards down the boardwalk, performing tricks and spinning the board. He eats shit, recovers, and looks off into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (V/O)
dialogues.text: People look at me...and they see my brother. That's how things have gone since the murder of our father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From afar, he spots a group of black gang members shoot hoops. He and Little Henry from earlier exchange a cold glance.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (V/O)
dialogues.text: Little Henry Hastings and his older brother Jerome. Jerome's a Shoreline Crip...Henry's on his way. Little Henry and older brother JEROME catch their breath and stare down Dan. Danny doesn't flinch. Jerome sips from a 40 oz. beer and resumes playing.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (V/O)
dialogues.text: Venice Beach, man. It didn't always look like this. I mean...our Dad used to take us down here to run...and it was cool. Derek fucking owned this place.        Since then though...the gangs, man-- TIGHT ON DANNy. He watches the basketball action as he takes a drag off his Marlboro Red.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY, (V/O)
dialogues.text: --they've moved west from Inglewood and South Central and have really just...taken over. Especially at my high school. The Venice Locos are big too but they hang out in bumluck Mar Vista. It's scary. (then) And then there's The Disciples of Christ. The D.O.C. Jerome and Little Henry joke and argue with eight extra players and spectators.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DANNY'S POV. The teams are a mixed assemblage of 3 blacks and 2 Latinos and 3 whites and 1 black and 1 Latino. SKINHEAD FAT SETH RYAN, early twenties, and his two skinhead buddies, can't compete against the better, predominantly black team. One of the skins, CURTIS, has a shaved head, a light beard and an M-16 RIFLE tattooed on his head. JEROME and LITTLE HENRY sit together to the right of the court and monitor closely. Danny looks over his left shoulder and sees Derek and Stacey sit with CAMMERON. Cowboy hat and BRONCO JERSEY, they sit and converse on the bleachers.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Seven-six. Let's go!  Set some picks!

dialogues.speaker: SETH
dialogues.text: Bring it on, boy. Derek quickly moves his eyes to the court.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Boy? Lawrence quickly pivots past Seth, dunks it, and yells as he hangs on the rim. The crowd cheers.

dialogues.speaker: SETH
dialogues.text: Lucky piece of shit! I'm through "monkeying" around with your ass! Lawrence spins around and challenges Seth.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Fat, pasty, pale, pastrami eating, cracker, motherfucker. A hundred bucks says I make you my bitch.

dialogues.speaker: SETH
dialogues.text: (to the crowd) Here we go! Trying to make ends meet for that cut in welfare. He makes a scene and passes Danny on the sideline. Lawrence waits for Seth to take it further. Danny looks at him, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It's eight-six, Seth.

dialogues.speaker: SETH
dialogues.text: When I want your fucking opinion I'll ask for it, fuckhead. (to Derek and Cam) Help me cover here, guys. Derek and Cameron stare at Seth, knowing Seth will lose and embarrass them.

dialogues.speaker: CAMMERON
dialogues.text: You got a big fucking mouth, fat kid.

dialogues.speaker: SETH
dialogues.text: I'll take this negro down.

dialogues.speaker: DEREK
dialogues.text: You can't take a shit, Seth.  Shut up. Derek shoots a look to Cameron, comes to a decision, and stands. He shouts for all to hear.

dialogues.speaker: DEREK
dialogues.text: I got a bet. Lawrence stares at him, sensing something harder.

dialogues.speaker: DEREK
dialogues.text: I come in, same score now, first one to eleven. Black boys against the white boys. Lawrence looks back to his boys in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Name your price, Cracker.

dialogues.speaker: DEREK
dialogues.text: No money...for the court. We win, you grab your shit and find a different place to run. Not just today... forever. You win, and we don't come back. No hitching, no fighting, here in front of everyone. Six-eight, our ball. The action around the court gets very still.  Finally, Lawrence nods.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: You got a lot of fucking balls, man. Bring it. Right now. Derek pulls off his sweatshirt and gives it to Stacey. Lawrence gets his team together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more mixed assemblage of players.  One team is white,  one team is black.

dialogues.speaker: A SERIES OF SMOTS
dialogues.text: Derek blows by Lawrence for a left handed layup. Derek hits a thirty looter. Curtis grabs a rebound and uses his elbows to get defenders off him. Big Lawrence fouls Derek hard and Derek stares at him. Big Lawrence makes a twenty foot turnaround. Lawrence advances on a three on two and dunks it. Derek pump fakes three times and uses the glass for a deuce. Finally, Derek drives the lane and dishes to Seth at the last minute for a bucket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! Ten a piece! Nice fucking dish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SETH and CURTIS slap Derek's hand as they get back on transition. Derek stares at Lawrence. CAMMERON watches intently.

dialogues.speaker: CAMMERON
dialogues.text: It's all you, Der!

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Fuckin' BYU, man!  All right!  All we need is one now! Lawrence and Derek lock eyes, a look exceeding competitive boundary. A look filled with rage.

dialogues.speaker: CAMMERON
dialogues.text: Use that fat ass and keep him out, Seth! Seth and the opposing player bang to get position underneath.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: I ain't losin' in my house!  Clear it  out! The POWER FORWARD dribbles beautifully up the court -- his teammates clearing out the key. Defensively, Derek is solid. He tries to pass Derek but Derek's defense is stifling. Again. With another tricky move, Lawrence inadvertently puts his LEFT ELBOW into Derek's face, sending him quickly to the pavement. EVERYBODY STOPS.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: That's fuckin' offense!

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Get the fuck outta here!  He was movin' his feet! Derek, teeth bloodied, rises. The two have a stare down.

dialogues.speaker: DEREK
dialogues.text: (threateningly) I'll go if you want to.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: You wanna piece! Bring it! Players quickly rush to restrain the two even though the teams hate each other.

dialogues.speaker: DEREK
